Award.AwardTitle: OCE-PRF An integrated study of the closure of the Central American Seaway: Exploring paleoceanography as a tool for broadening participation in ocean sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Overview: The closure of the Central American Seaway (CAS) and resulting Isthmus of Panama have shaped much of our understanding of the adaptation and migration of species between North and South America, as well as the diversification of Pacific and Caribbean marine species. Until recently, the CAS was thought to have closed between approximately 9 and 2 Ma; however, new studies of Panamanian geology suggest the isthmus was sub-aerially exposed by the Early Miocene (approximately 23 Ma). As dramatic global change has been ascribed to the previously accepted timing of this gateway event, the new findings raise many questions regarding the role the closure may have had on ocean circulation, climate, and paleoecology. In this project, the fellow will further investigate the timing and oceanographic impacts of the CAS closure through the development of neodymium (Nd) isotopic records of Caribbean water mass distribution that extend well beyond the presumed Late Miocene closure date, and direct comparison of these data to oceanic model simulations for CAS shoaling. The proposed work will be conducted in the Department of Geological Sciences at the University of Florida (UF) with the sponsorship of Ellen E. Martin, PhD.

Intellectual Merit: In order to reconstruct a long-term history of CAS shoaling, Nd-isotopic analyses will be performed on fossil fish teeth recovered from Caribbean Ocean Drilling Program Sites 998, 999, and 1000 for samples extending back to approximately 50 Ma. This record will be used to evaluate the presence of older complete or pulsed closure events predicted by recent geologic findings from Panama, and provide a baseline of conditions prior to shoaling. The fellow hypothesizes that earlier shoaling events produced excursions towards more negative, Atlantic-type, Nd-isotope values that predate those observed in late Miocene sediments; however, these excursions must be transient in nature to reconcile the Pacific signatures documented for the Caribbean between approximately 14 to 10 Ma. The existence of such excursions would corroborate recent studies showing a much earlier rise of the Isthmus of Panama and require a re-evaluation of the associated global ocean circulation, climate, and biogeographic data, while the absence of such excursions would call into question interpretations of earlier complete sub-aerial exposure of Panama. Through the integration of newly generated water mass reconstructions, compilations of marine and terrestrial records from the literature, and modeling of oceanic circulation in collaboration with colleagues, the long-term paleoceanographic shoaling history of the CAS will be documented and its generally accepted associations with global ocean circulation and climate re-evaluated in light of this new information.

Broader Impacts: This project will add an oceanographic component to the ongoing efforts of a diverse scientific community studying the rise of the Isthmus via the Panama Canal Project - Partnership for International Research and Education. The fellow will mentor and collaborate with two female minority graduate students pursuing complementary marine research on the project in otherwise terrestrially oriented departments. Two undergraduate students, selected with the goal of broadening participation, will be mentored and involved in all aspects of the proposed research; one of these students will also be supervised in the completion of a related Honors thesis. Additionally, the fellow will design and implement a hands-on introduction to an ocean science module using a major Miocene carbonate dissolution event in the Caribbean as an analog for modern ocean acidification. The module will be integrated into the broader curricula for the California Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Teachers Partnership that exposes high school educators, and by extension their students, to unique international science opportunities in order to advance discovery and understanding, and promote a community of teaching, training, and learning. Six teachers from two Santa Cruz school districts with substantial Hispanic populations will participate, allowing for dissemination of ocean awareness to thousands of diverse high school students and encouraging STEM pursuits with a focus on ocean sciences. Finally, broad exposure of the public to ocean science and paleoceanographic research will be achieved via active participation in outreach and education initiatives through the UF, Center for Ocean Sciences Education Excellence (COSEE) Florida, Sea Grant, and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. This participation will include, though not be limited to, development of a paleoceanography booth for the annual "Can you dig it?" event at the Florida Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  Recent geologic studies have suggested that the Isthmus of Panama rose, closing the Central American Seaway (CAS), much earlier than previously thought. An early rise scenario would call into question many of the dramatic changes in the distribution of life, ocean circulation, and global climate that have been ascribed to this gateway event. In order to investigate the presence of paleoceanographic evidence for earlier closure of the CAS, this study reconstructed the long-term history of water mass distribution in the Caribbean using neodymium (Nd) isotopic signatures recorded by fish teeth and debris in marine sediments. Ocean Drilling Program Site 998 and 999 Nd-isotopic records were extended to ~50 million years (Ma) ago and a new record was developed from intermediate depth Site 1000 from 20 Ma to present.

Overall, the reconstruction from Site 998 indicates a gradual increase in Nd-isotope values from 50 to 13 Ma that is in keeping with increasing volcanism around the Pacific during the Cenozoic. After 13 Ma, the Nd-isotope records from all three sites increase to values consistent with Pacific intermediate waters, suggesting a marked shallowing of the CAS, before beginning their steady decline towards the Atlantic-type Nd-isotope values we see in the Caribbean today. The coherence of the records from deep water Sites 998 and 999 and intermediate depth Site 1000 from 13 Ma to present suggests a well-mixed Caribbean over this interval. However, the new reconstructions show no excursions to more negative, Atlantic-type, Nd-isotope values prior to 10 Ma as would be expected for early closure events. Subsequently, this research corroborates the abundance of published marine and terrestrial evidence that supports a sustained waterway connection between the Pacific and Atlantic oceans until at least 8 Ma ago.

This study also aimed to assess the fidelity of the Nd-isotope proxy for water mass distribution and ocean circulation in marine sediments from aerially exposed outcrops in the tropics. Marine sediments dating from the CAS were collected from outcrops at four localities across Panama. Fossil fish teeth, bone, scales, and shark denticles isolated from these sediments were analyzed for rare earth element concentrations and Nd-isotopic composition. While the individual fossil components within each locality exhibited similar Nd-isotopic signatures, the values were much more positive, or radiogenic, than those documented for ocean waters. Similar exceptionally positive Nd-isotope values were also measured in sections of the ODP Site 999 core that were rich in volcanic ash, suggesting that the isotopic signatures of these fish fossils have been influenced by highly radiogenic sea and/or pore water resulting from intense regional volcanism. Subsequently, this study provides an important caveat for future efforts to apply the Nd-isotope proxy in volcanic regions. The scientific findings of this research have been presented at three professional conferences and in invited talks at two collaborative institutions abroad.

Broader Impacts:  This fellowship supported my addition of an oceanographic component to the ongoing interdisciplinary efforts within the Panama Canal Project - Partnership for International Research and Education. The scope of the grant provided a platform for the training, mentorship and inclusion of 11 diverse high school to graduate level students in paleoceanographic techniques, including sediment collection and processing, clean lab chemistry, and analysis via mass spectrometry. Three of these students were able to pursue related independent research projects that they ultimately went on to present at international seminars and professional meetings.

Through my role as a scientific advisor and mentor with the 2015 and 2016 cohorts of the Great American Biotic Interchange - Research Experience for Teachers, I was able to develop and provide relevant paleoceanographic content to twenty six K-12 teachers from U.S. schools, many of which have substantial minority populations. My participation included giving seminars, leading discussions and field excursions, and collaborating with teachers to develop Next Generation Science Standard-aligned curriculum for their classrooms that built off of their field and laboratory experiences through the program. The developed lessons were presented at a professional meeting and will be made publicly accessible via the program website. I further coordinated and executed a field-based Marine Fossil Workshop for youth from the Cambio Creativo program in Panama that allowed us to share our teams’ knowledge and expertise with Panamanian children local to our field sites and challenged our teachers to develop relevant field-based lessons for a Spanish speaking audience. Additionally, I independently designed and implemented, with the support of University of Florida graduate students, hands-on lessons related to the interactions between ocean circulation, climate, and life on Earth for numerous middle school classes as part of the Alachua County Speakers’ Bureau. These ocean circulation and paleoceanography activities were further adapted for use during public outreach through the Florida Museum of Natural History, including the University of Florida Department of Geological Sciences’ Can you dig it? and Girl Scouts’ She’s a Scientist! events.
